content.text: **Informal fallacies** are errors in reasoning that arise from content or context rather than logical form. Unlike invalid argument forms (formal fallacies), these require judgment to identify.

content.definition: Attacking the person making an argument rather than the argument itself. The character or circumstances of an arguer don't determine whether their argument is good.

content.title: Ad Hominem Fallacy
premises: Dr. Smith argues that smoking causes cancer.
But Dr. Smith is funded by a health organization.
content.conclusion: Therefore, smoking probably doesn't cause cancer.
content.note: The funding source doesn't refute the scientific evidence. Attack the argument, not the arguer.

content.definition: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack. You 'defeat' a weaker version of what they actually said.

content.title: Straw Man Fallacy
premises: Person A: 'We should have stricter environmental regulations.'
Person B: 'So you want to destroy all businesses and jobs?'
content.conclusion: Person B has distorted Person A's position.
content.note: Stricter regulations â‰  destroying businesses. This is an unfair characterization.

symbols.name: Misrepresent Position
symbols.meaning: Attack a distorted version of the view
symbols.example: So you think we should just...

symbols.name: Only Two Options
symbols.meaning: Present limited choices when more exist
symbols.example: Either you're with us or against us

symbols.name: Chain of Doom
symbols.meaning: Claim small step leads to disaster
symbols.example: If we allow X, then Y, then Z...

content.text: Not all appeals to authority are fallacious. It's reasonable to trust experts in their field. The fallacy occurs when the authority isn't relevant (Einstein on religion) or when expert opinion replaces evidence.

content.question: "You can't trust John's argument for recycling - he drives an SUV!" This is an example of:
options: Ad hominem - attacking John instead of his argument
False dilemma - presenting only two options
content.explanation: This is ad hominem because it attacks John's character (he drives an SUV) rather than addressing his actual argument for recycling. John's vehicle choice doesn't affect whether his argument about recycling is good or bad.
